lines.text:
[to Perrache]
Pick out anyone you like, someone out of a crowd, the more anonymous the better. The individual you choose it totally unimportant. He's to bait the hook. All that counts is that Milan must swallow it.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: This is getting on my nerves, this is getting on my nerves, this is getting on my nerves, this is getting on my nerves!

[in Christine's bathroom]
My nose is bleeding. It's stopped now, but I got hit with a bagpipe.
A bagpipe?
A bagpipe.

[he's startled Milan by coming up behind him]
You're very nervous, Bernard.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: It's just that I didn't realize you were behind me, sir.
Oh, but I'm not. As usual, I'm way ahead of you.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[they're both sitting in Perrin's apartment]
I've got to pee.

[looks at him, then]
Go ahead.

[gets up, goes over to Perrin and holds out his hand]
Come with me.

[he's dying from a gunshot in Perrin's apartment; Perrache slowly opens the door and enters]
Perrache?
[Perache comes over to him and bends over him]
The tall blond... with the black shoe... who is he?
[Perraxche straightens up and looks about him at Poucet's dead body and the unconscious Maurice; Milan looks at him pleadingly]

[pause, then]
A fool's trap, sir.
[Milan, realizing the truth, dies with a smile]
Milan must have a lesson. It's most unpleasant to have a colleague who uses Counter-Espionage for his own purposes.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[referring to Milan's agents]
It's really disagreable to have so many agents in my office whom I've never met.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[reporting to Colonel Toulouse]
There are three victims, sir... two of Milan's men and Chaperon.

[looks up sharply]
I beg your pardon?
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: Yes, sir, I'm afraid there was shooting. But you needn't worry... the Tall Blond is quite safe.

[pause, then slowly leans back in his chair]
I thought I told you to call off Poucet and... Chaperon.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[pretending surprise]
Oh, really? Well, I guess I misunderstood. I told them to tighten up their surveillance.

[coldly]
You *did* misunderstand me, I fear.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: I'm sorry, sir.
[Toulouse leans forward and stares hard at him]
I've always obeyed orders. I presumed that you'd want to protect the innocent.

[slowly leans back]
Unfortunately, it's no use, Perrache. Things have gone too far; it's Milan's turn to come on stage. On one hand we have Milan with his guilty conscience and on the other the Tall Blond with One Black Shoe. This affair will have to end in a shooting match... just like all good Westerns.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[leaving Perrin's building in a daze when he runs into Perrin coming in]
There are three dead men in your house.
Eh?
I came looking for you. I came here to shoot you... but there are three dead men in your house.
[last lines]

[watching footage of Perrin and Christine leaving for Rio at Orly Airport]
When he comes back from Rio...
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: Yes, sir?
And he *will* come back eventually... I want you to contact him. After all, he handles himself pretty well.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[Milan is berating her for not being able to seduce Perrin]
When could I have worked with my head? He began the evening having his zipper caught in my hair. After that, he got a bloody nose, I heard his opera and I had to make love with him twice!
[half to herself]
And he's good at it, too!
There was another fellow at Orly... a black fellow in a green overcoat. I prferred a tall blond man with one black shoe to a black fellow in a green overcoat.

[looks at Perrache, then]
Listen, my friend, we're not being paid to philosophize. Wait until you've retired.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[to Colonel Toulouse, referring to Milan]
You should remind him that he's not in the Service just to spend his time trying to find ways to steal your job.

[talking about Perrache's choice at Orly]
But why a violinist?
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: You told me to choose anyone at all.
Yes, but why a violinist?
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text: Because he had one black shoe.
[Toulouse looks at him]

[referring to the possibility of Perrin's getting killed]
It wouldn't bother you at all to send an innocent lamb to slaughter?
And you? The Tall Blond Man with One Black Shoe was *your* choice. Is your conscience bothering you now?
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse

lines.text:
[pause, then]
No, sir.

[referring to Perrin]
He's right out of a circus!

[on the phone with Botrel]
He's flushing the toilet? What do you mean, he's flushing the toilet? Yes, I know, but there's got to be a reason he keeps on flushing it!

[about his unfaithful wife Paulette]
But I've already told you, she's in a delivery truck with a horse!

[to Toulouse, referring to Milan]
What a character! Carload of heroin, mikes in statues... he's really out for your blood.

[being informed over the phone about Perrin's latest activities]
He's throwing bread to the ducks? Oh, my God!

[reporting to Toulouse about Perrin's meeting with Christine]
They're making love at her place, 85 Rue des Vignes.
You see, he has some compensations after all, your unfortunate protege.
lines.character: Le colonel Louis Marie Alphonse Toulouse
